title: 110_hr5738
content: The Act is titled the "Commercial Seafood Consumer Protection Act" and focuses on seafood safety. The Commercial Seafood Consumer Protection Act mandates the Secretary of Commerce, in collaboration with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to establish a program ensuring that seafood in the US meets federal food safety laws. A memorandum of understanding between the two secretaries will enhance cooperation on seafood safety, including examining imports, coordinating foreign facility inspections, and providing technical assistance for marine aquaculture. The Commercial Seafood Consumer Protection Act mandates collaboration between the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Health and Human Services to ensure seafood safety in the US. This includes developing processes for expediting seafood imports, tracking shipments within the US, enforcing labeling requirements, and commissioning officers for seafood examinations. The collaboration between the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Health and Human Services includes seafood examinations, sharing non-compliance information, and conducting joint training to strengthen seafood inspection effectiveness. Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will expand the number of certified laboratories for analyzing seafood to ensure compliance with Federal law. The list of certified laboratories will be published in the Federal Register and updated annually. In any fiscal year after this Act, the Secretary of Commerce will increase NOAA laboratories' number and capacity for testing and activities as needed. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can refuse entry of seafood imports from a country if they may not meet Federal law requirements. If there are not enough certified laboratories, increased testing of seafood shipments from that country will be ordered to detect violations. The Secretary may allow individual shipments of seafood from a country or exporter into the US if certified by a lab and inspected to meet Federal law requirements. The Secretary can cancel an order for seafood exports from a country. The Secretary can allow individual seafood shipments from a country or exporter into the US if they meet Federal law requirements. If an exporter fails to comply with an order, the 1-year period for shipments will start from the date of that determination. Reliable evidence includes the detection of failure to meet Federal law requirements by the Secretary. The section outlines the detection of non-compliance of seafood products through various means, including inspections, investigations, and findings from other countries. It clarifies that this section does not affect the authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. SEC. 6. INSPECTION TEAMS. The Secretary of Commerce, with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will send inspectors to assess seafood exporters for prohibited drugs or practices. A report will be published in the Federal Register within 90 days of the inspection, and countries can offer a rebuttal within 90 days of the report's publication. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2013 is set at $15,000,000 to carry out the provisions of this Act.
